_comment: Example track: Art History. This shows how to structure a non-programming track.

track.name: Art History Foundations
track.description: Learn to analyze, interpret, and appreciate art through hands-on projects. From visual analysis to cultural context, develop the skills to engage deeply with any artwork.

projects.name: Personal Museum Guide
projects.description: Create a curated guide to 5 artworks that moved you. Learn to describe what you see and articulate why art affects you.

milestones.name: Select Works
milestones.description: Choose 5 artworks from any museum or online collection

milestones.name: Describe What You See
milestones.description: Write purely visual descriptionsâ€”no research yet

milestones.name: Identify Elements
milestones.description: Break down line, color, shape, composition

projects.name: Art Detective
projects.description: Given an unknown artwork, research and identify its origins. Learn to use visual clues and historical context.

milestones.name: Visual Inventory
milestones.description: Document everything visible in the work

milestones.name: Style Clues
milestones.description: Identify stylistic markers that suggest period/region

milestones.name: Historical Research
milestones.description: Connect to historical events and patronage

milestones.name: Attribution Report
milestones.description: Write up your findings with evidence

projects.name: Comparative Analysis Essay
projects.description: Write a scholarly comparison of two artworks. Master the art of drawing meaningful connections.

milestones.name: Select Pair
milestones.description: Choose two works with an interesting relationship

milestones.name: Identify Connections
milestones.description: Find formal, thematic, or historical links

milestones.name: Develop Thesis
milestones.description: Craft an argument about their relationship

misconceptions.name: Immediate Interpretation
misconceptions.description: Jumping to meaning before describing what's actually visible
misconceptions.trigger_answer: This painting represents the artist's sadness
misconceptions.remediation_strategy: Separate observation from interpretation. First: What do you SEE? Only then: What might it MEAN?

misconceptions.name: Universal Symbolism
misconceptions.description: Assuming symbols mean the same thing across all cultures and time periods
misconceptions.remediation_strategy: Symbols are culturally specific. Research the specific time and place to understand intended meaning.

misconceptions.name: Style as Chronological
misconceptions.description: Believing artistic styles follow a strict timeline
misconceptions.remediation_strategy: Styles overlap, coexist, and revival. Focus on characteristics, not just dates.

diagnostic_questions.code_snippet: [Image: A landscape painting with mountains, a river, and figures]
diagnostic_questions.correct_answer: Diagonal lines lead the eye from the lower left corner to the mountain peak

distractors.answer: This painting represents humanity's struggle against nature
The artist was influenced by Romanticism
This was probably painted in the 19th century

diagnostic_questions.code_snippet: [Image: Renaissance painting with a figure holding a key]
diagnostic_questions.prompt: To understand the key's meaning, what should you do first?
diagnostic_questions.correct_answer: Research what keys symbolized in Renaissance religious art

distractors.answer: Assume it means access or power, as keys do today
Look at the artist's biography for personal significance
Ignore it as a minor detail
